title: What to Do This Summer So Kids Don't Forget Math
description: Prevent summer slide without turning vacation into school. Practical low-effort strategies.
imageAlt: Child doing light math practice during summer

content.intro: Studies show students lose 2+ months of math skills over summer. But turning vacation into "school at home" backfires. Here's the balance.

items: Students lose 2-2.5 months of math computation skills on average
Teachers spend 4-6 weeks in fall re-teaching
The loss compounds year over year
Lower-income students often lose more due to less access

sections.text: But here's the good news: even minimal summer practice (15-20 min, 3-4x/week) prevents most of the loss.
Summer isn't the time to push ahead. It's about not falling behind. Lower your expectations (and theirs). Just keep the engine running.
School year: daily. Summer: 3-4x per week. Less pressure, still effective.
10-15 minutes max. It's summer. Don't make them resent math right before a new school year.
Workbooks feel like homework. Apps feel like screen time. Same practice, different vibe.
5. Make It Part of the Routine
"Math after breakfast on Monday, Wednesday, Friday" is easier to maintain than random "we should do some math today."
Going somewhere for a week or two? Options:

items: Bring the tablet – 10 minutes on the beach won't ruin vacation
Take a full break – one week off won't cause major slide
Do only real-world math – travel provides natural practice

rows: ✅ 15 min app practice OR real-world math activity

sections.text: That's 45 minutes total per week. Enough to maintain, not enough to feel like school.

faq.question: Should I advance to next year's material?
faq.answer: Generally no. Review and maintain current year skills. Let school introduce new content with proper instruction.

faq.question: What if my child is already behind?
faq.answer: Summer can be catch-up time, but go slow. 4-5x per week of slightly longer sessions. Don't try to cram a year into two months.

faq.question: My child attends summer programs – is that enough?
faq.answer: Maybe! If the program includes academic components, you might not need additional practice. Check what they're doing.

faq.question: Is this advice suitable for all ages?
faq.answer: The strategies discussed are primarily designed for children ages 5-12, but many principles can be adapted for different age groups.

faq.question: How long does it take to see results?
faq.answer: Results vary by child, but most parents notice improvements within 2-4 weeks of consistent practice.

faq.question: Do I need special materials or equipment?
faq.answer: Most activities can be done with everyday items. For Soroban-specific learning, the Sorokid app provides a virtual abacus.

faq.question: Can I use these methods alongside school curriculum?
faq.answer: Absolutely! These approaches are designed to complement, not replace, what children learn at school.
